SENT.plain: OBJECTIVES: Rigosertib (ON 01910.Na, Estybon) is a novel, anticancer agent undergoing phase 3 clinical trials for a lead indication against myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS)

In this research, the permeability of rigosertib was evaluated using the in-situ perfused rat intestine (IPRI) model to support development of an oral formulation for rigosertib for treating cancer patients
METHODS: Experiments (n = 6 per group) were conducted using male Sprague-Dawley rats
Studies evaluated permeability across various intestinal segments and assessed the dose-linearity of absorption over the entire intestinal length
Drug concentrations in the portal and jugular vein were collected to correlate permeability parameters with presystemic and systemic exposure
KEY FINDINGS: Rigosertib permeability was highest in the jejunum, although parameter estimates indicated that rigosertib was a medium permeability compound
The compound displayed nonlinear absorption in the IPRI model, suggesting a saturable transport process
Transport inhibition studies using Caco-2 cells demonstrated that rigosertib was a P-glycoprotein (P-gp) substrate
Absolute bioavailability of rigosertib (10 and 20 mg/kg, 1-h infusion) in rats was estimated to be 10-15%
However, the fraction absorbed in humans predicted from IPRI data (52%) was consistent with published clinical data for rigosertib (35% oral bioavailability)
CONCLUSIONS: The results of this research indicated that rigosertib is a promising candidate for oral delivery
Further studies are needed to evaluate the potential impact of P-gp and other intestinal transporters on the oral absorption of this promising anticancer agent
